subject: Re: [junit] Setup inheritance
msgSnippet: I probably meant inheritance in Java, as in extends, implements, super and all that rot. You re not lumping me in with the long-winded are you? :)
messageBody:
I probably meant "inheritance in Java," as in extends, implements,
super and all that rot.

You're not lumping me in with the "long-winded" are you? :)

*********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********

On 2002-07-19 at 07:36 Eric Heikkila wrote:

>Read up on inheritence? hehehe...funny. You can
>probably sum it up in one sentence.
>
>Of course, then, the long-winded and/or 'teacher' (or
>certifier) types out there would be out of a job. ;)
>
>-Eric
>
>--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
>wrote:
>> Hm. I think our original poster just missed out on a
>> chance to learn
>> something.
>>
>> To the original poster: please read up on
>> inheritance anyway -- if
>> you're a student, then it's good for you to know
>> about, and if you're a
>> professional, people out there will assume you know
>> it.
>>
>> Best of luck.
>>
>> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
>>
>> On 2002-07-18 at 15:46 Eric Heikkila wrote:
>>
>> >Shorter answer...
>> >
>> >... make sure you have something like the
>> following:
>> >
>> >public BaseClass extends TestCase {
>> >
>> > public void setUp() {
>> > System.out.println("BaseClass");
>> > }
>> >}
>> >
>> >public KiddieClass extends BaseClass {
>> > public void setUp() {
>> > super.setUp();
>> > System.out.println("Kiddie");
>> > }
>> >}
>> >
>> >----------------------------------------
>> >(Make sure you're calling super.setUp() in the
>> child
>> >classes).
>> >
>> >
